_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Central Farm Service

233 West Ciro Street

PO Box 68

Truman, MN 56088

Risk Management Plan - EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Facility:



The Coop board, management and employees at Central Farm Service, Granada, MN location, are committed to the prevention of accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.



2. Facility Information and Regulated Substance:



The primary activity at the facility involves the storage of fertilizers for sale to farmers. Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, handled and distributed for direct application. Anhydrous ammonia is used for crop production nutrients.



The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia would be approximately one-18,000 and one-12,000 gallon storage tanks; and approximately 184,900 pounds available capacity in various 1,450,and 1,000 gallon nurse tanks. The maximum quantity handled at one time would be the unloading of a tank truck holding 40,000-45,000 pounds.



3. General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:



The facility has implemented Minnesota Dept. of Agriculture rules, the Standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia; and 40 CFR part 68 as they apply to this facility. The facility is required to conduct a semi-annual inspection of all bulk and nurse tank equipment, including load and unload equipment, and perform any needed maintenance to the equipment found during the inspections. Visual checks are to be conducted daily at the facility.



4. The Five-year Accident History:  



There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that have to our knowledge: 



a) Caused

any death, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; or 

b) To our knowledge resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage.



5. The Emergency Response Program:  



The facility has:



a. A written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38 and 40 CFR 68.95. The plan includes a specific section on NH3 Releases and what to do in the event of a release. The next annual emergency action plan training is scheduled for July 2018. Additional emergency response training is also provided throughout the year at various training sessions, including but not limited to a training session specifically on anhydrous ammonia held every fall.



b. Provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA);



c. Coordinated with local emergency responders.



d. A Safety Data Sheet for anhydrous ammonia as part of their emergency response plan information for quick access and reference.



e. A Minnesota AWAIR (A Workplace Accident and Injury Reduction) program in place and is committed to a safe working environment as well as protection of the community in which we operate.



6.Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.  Central Farm Service plans to continue education and training for employees along with periodic inspections by the local fire department.
